title: john bercow brexit bbc interview
story: The Commons Speaker made a string of sarcastic jokes when he was approached by the BBC this morning.He ignored repeated questions about his controversial move to stop Theresa May holding a third vote on his Brexit deal.Mr Bercow was filmed walking to work in Parliament and asked: Can you explain to the public what you did yesterday But instead of responding, he said, I really feel you ought to get yourselves some coffee or tea - then made a joke about the reporters hat.Pressed on the issue, the Speaker sneered: Im sure people are so very grateful to you for showing such interest at this time in the morning - very grateful to you, very well done.As the camera crew crossed the road with him, Mr Bercow snapped: Careful, careful! There are cars coming along here, Im not going to sacrice myself for your benefit.I know that you attach great weight to what you think, but perhaps youd be kind enough to allow me to proceed.Yesterday the Speaker, who has near-total control over the Commons, cited a -year-old precedent which stops MPs from tabling the same questions again and again.Mr Bercow said the rule prevented the PM from bringing her Brexit deal back for a third meaningful vote after it was defeated twice.His edict was welcomed by hardline Brexiteers keen to go for No Deal - but also by Remainers who want to overturn Brexit entirely.Tory MP James Gray today predicted the Speakers move would kill off our EU exit for good.He said: As a result of Mr Bercows ruling yesterday there will be a huge extension to A over the weekend, No Deal is off the table.My suspicion is that this is the end of Brexit - I dont think that Britain will leave the European Union.

title: theresa may begging eu brexit deal
story: If Theresa May can on Tuesday win the vote on her Brexit deal at the third time of asking, then the road ahead will become much clearer.Butshe loses again, this country’s future will — to an uncomfortable extent — be in the hands of the European Union.The DUP, with its ten MPs, will be key to what happens.If the Government can satisfy them, then Mrs May has a chance of winning the vote because of the domino effect them coming across will set off.If she can’t, she — as No aides admit — might as well not bother holding one.The DUP spent yesterday in intensive talks with senior Government figures. I under­stand these talks were broadly positive. One Cabinet minister close to the process tells me the chances of the DUP backing the deal are, “a bit better than :. I’d put it at :”.What is winning round the DUP is the promise of putting into the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which puts the deal into UK law, a requirement that there be no ergence between Northern Ireland and Britain.The Withdrawal Agreement Bill would be so-called superior legislation. This would mean it would trump any other bill, giving the DUP some reassurance that the next Prime Minister couldn’t let regulatory dferences emerge between the rest of the UK and Northern Ireland.Parliament will also be given a scrutiny power over the backstop, allowing it to vote every few years on how it is operating.At the same time, the UK Government will seek to offer the DUP some reassurance about this country’s ability to get out of the backstop. I am told thatAttorney General Geoffrey Cox’s legal advice had been dferent, then the DUP would have been on board this week. One Cabinet minister tells me:“Geoffrey did cost the DUP.”To sweeten the deal for the DUP, there will be money and ladles of respect. The DUP want a new “policy package” to replace their confidence and supply deal with the Tories which runs out in June.To say that these negotiations are delicate would be an understatement. I am told, “ people put too much pressure on them, there’s a danger that they’ll bolt”.But with this Speaker and this Parliament any hopes for a better one, or for a clean break, seem for the birds.As James Forsyth says, the “big beasts” of the backbenches must show some leadership.Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab and Iain Duncan Smith were leading lights of the Leave campaign, but by not backing the deal they are now imperilling the whole project. They won’t be forgiven.Good card players know when to hold ’em and know when to fold ’em.Wise politicians must be no dferent.Butthe Government can get the DUP, it is confident that Jacob Rees-Mogg will then come on board.Despite voting against the deal on Tuesday, European Research Group chairman Rees-Mogg left himself a ladder to climb down, repeat­edly declaring that the only reason to vote for this deal wasBrexit was in genuine danger.After the Commons voted against No Deal and for an extension, it clearly is.The big question is how many Brexiteer rebels climb down Jacob’s ladder. Downing Street think there are  to  Tory diehards who won’t vote for the deal even with the DUP on board.The precise number is absolutely crucial. As one senior Downing Street source explains: “If it is at the lower end of that scale, it can be made up with Labour. If it is at the higher end, it can’t be.”There are, I’m told, between  and  Labour MPs prepared to back a deal but onlyit has a realistic chance of passing. Influential figures in the Cabinet are urging No to make the vote on Tuesday a free vote, to make it easier for Labour MPs to support it.If the deal doesn’t pass on Tuesday, then Mrs May will have to go to the European Council on Thursday and beg for a full-on extension to the Article  process. I am told she is dreading this personal and national humiliation.The Commons should spare her and, more importantly, the country, that.RIGHT now there is little sign that either Boris Johnson or Dominic Raab are going to move and back the Brexit deal.Both feel that their reservations about it are still too strong.But there is a danger for them both –  Tory Eurosceptics voted against the deal on Tuesday night.Whatever happens with the DUP, that number will drop a bit when the meaningful vote comes back for a third time.The danger for Boris and Raab is thatthey walk through the lobbies with this shrinking group, they will start to be seen as purely factional candidates, and purely factional candidates rarely win leadership contests.Already some of those who backed Boris last time and had been planning to do so again are peeling away.Now is a moment that calls for bigness.If either Boris or Raab were prepared to say that – despite their reservations – they were going to try to get the deal over the line, because Brexit is only going to get softer otherwise, they would show they have the selflessness necessary to lead.WHEN your voice is going, what’s the last thing that you want  A meeting with a heavy smoker.But that is what Theresa May had to contend with on Monday after she flew to Strasbourg for last-minute talks with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.By Wednesday, Mrs May’s voice was so bad that No had a plan for Andrea Leadsom,  to take over halfway through PMQsher voice gave out completely.TO get people to do things you need both a carrot and a stick.But the problem for the Government is that its warnings to Brexiteer rebels are all stick.It is pointing out that Brexit will only get softerMPs don’t vote for the deal. This is right, but these MPs need a positive inducement too.One Tory who carries messages from Theresa May’s Downing Street to the Brexiteer rebels tells me: “If she offered to go, she would get very close and possibly do it.“It unlocks those people whose self-perception is that they don’t give in to blackmail.” This source continues: “If the DUP move, Jacobmoves,Jacob moves others follow, but you don’t quite get there without the carrot.”Mrs May could leave with dignity, having secured an orderly Brexit and having managed to avoid a split in the Tory party.She wouldn’t need to leave the next day, either.But just in time to ensure that a new Prime Minister had their feet firmly under the desk before a new European Commission comes into office this autumn.One reason why an indication that May will go is so important is that there is assumption she will try to staythe withdrawal agreement passes.One Cabinet minister tells me: “If she gets a deal through, she won’t be able to resist clinging on.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsBrexit:  fast facts you need today as UK faces major constitutional crisisTheresa Mays plans were blown out of the water by the Commons Speaker John Bercow - and they could now go to war as the Cabinet meets with just  days left legally until BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video brexit-secretary-stephen-barclay-suggests-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is mulling her next steps this morning after her Brexit plan was spectacularly torpedoed by the House of Commons Speaker. story: NewsJohn Bercow briefly silent for once as Speaker is ambushed by BBC over BrexitThe verbose House of Commons Speaker merrily chatted away about coffee and bobble hats - but was zipped up when asked about his actual decision to rule out a "substantially similar" third vote on BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video john-bercow-refuses-answer-questions-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email John Bercow became infected with a severe case of silence today as the Commons Speaker was confronted by the BBC over Brexit .Wearing cream trousers and a stripy jumper, the MP was ambushed in the drizzle outside Parliament after he blocked a third vote on Theresa Mayaposs Brexit deal. story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: John Bercow bravely put a stop to Groundhog MayThe Prime Minister is stuck after the Commons Speaker dusted down historic rules to stop meaningless Brexit bill repeat attemptsShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAR NewsopinionJohn Bercow dropped a Brexit bombshell on Theresa May "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is stuck after Commons Speaker John Bercow’s Brexit bombshell. title: 7 brexit terms no one
story: Advertorial Brexit terms no-one ever wants to hear ever againThere are now several phrases and terms which have sufferers of Brexit fatigue people running as soon as they hear themShareByRichard Innes:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR AdvertorialYep, that just about sums it up "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPerhaps the most devastating damage caused by Brexit has been to the English language. You see, one of the ways politicians and journalists have coped with the mind-numbing drudgery of having to spend all day, every day, for two years talking about something as fundamentally boring as our departure from the EU, is by making up shorthand words to describe it. But that’s left the rest of the country with a hellish glossary of meaningless jargon and confusing buzz-words. Here’s seven words, terms and phrases that nobody will miss when they’re gone. Article   The biggest problem with making people interested in Brexit is that it’s very similar to Star Wars Episode I. Stay with me. After Jar Jar Binks, the most commonly cited reason for Star Wars Episode I being rubbish is that it opens with the Jedi Knights, the last defenders of peace and justice in the galaxy, turning up to help negotiate a dispute over trade tarfs. Literal magical wizards with laser swords were rendered tedious by thrusting them into an argument about taxes. What we should have learned from that is that evenBritain had sent Obi Wan Kenobi to Brussels to deliver our Article  notication, people still wouldn’t care what it was or what was in it, because it’s fundamentally boring. Backstop  Nothing gets hard-Brexiteers quite as furious as the idea that we could be trapped in the Northern Ireland ‘backstop’ for all eternity. But convincing the public that a backstop is a bad thing is a hard sell for the British public. You see, we all grew up being told backstops were good things. Specically, they’re the best fielding position in Rounders. You feel involved in the action and get to do loads of throwing and catching, but the likelihood of having to actually run around anywhere is minimal. Good luck trying to demonise the word ‘backstop’, Jacob Rees-Mogg. We’re reclaiming it for the great British, lazy, glory hunter. No-deal  Until the Summer of , ‘no deal’ was something that people only really said to Noel Edmonds’ imaginary friend. And that’s why the Government is now struggling to convince people that no-deal would leave them materially worse off.    In Deal or No Deal, the worst-box scenario is that you go home with p and Noel’s tanned, wrinkly sympathy face forever burned on your retina for all time. Gamble wrong on Brexit and you’re stockpiling water puriers and eating freeze-dried fish from a bag. Meaningful vote  Theresa May is a woman of many talents, but perhaps her greatest gt is her ability to take basic elements of the English language and strip them of all logic and relevance. Take the ‘meaningful vote’, for example. Presumably it was named that so MPs would think that whatever decision was taken in such a vote would be in some way binding. Now we’re staring down the barrel of a third meaningful vote, and the word meaningful has lost all meaning. It was a meaningless vote. Buccaneering  This is what Brexiteers reckon Britain will be once we leave the EU. A buccaneering trading nation, cutting a swath through the high seas and selling our wares to eager countries across the globe.    And the man in charge of that  International Trade Secretary Liam Fox. A man who looks like he probably gets seasick on the pirate ship at Alton Towers. A swashbuckler he is not. Future relationship  Nobody ever wants to have the conversation about ‘where this relationship is going’. It inevitably leads either to a messy, acrimonious breakup or one of you getting a dog when you don’t want to. Same deal with Europe. There’s a reason Brussels is putting this one off until after we’ve got Northern Ireland sorted. Brexit

title: abusive ex told pregnant partner
story: NewsAbusive ex told pregnant partner Im going to boot that baby clean out of youRobert Christopher Fay threatened to blow up a BMW and told Lisa Edwards, , he would get to her before police got to him, North East Wales Magistrates Court heardShareCommentsByKelly Williams:,  MAR NewsRobert Christopher Fay threatened his ex repeatedly, North East Wales Magistrates Court heard"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who bombarded his pregnant ex with terrying messages saying he was going to boot the baby clean out of her has been spared jail. Robert Christopher Fay warned Lisa Edwards that he would get to her before police got to him. Fay, , also threatened to blow up a BMW and smash all the windows of Ms Edwardsapos home in a series of texts sent on March .Fay pleaded guilty to making offensive communications at North East Wales Magistratesapos Court at Mold yesterday, North Wales Live reports.Justin Espie, prosecuting, said the matter was a domestic case involving his ex who heaposd been on and off with for  years and with whom he has two children and another on the way.  Mr Espie said messages from Fay started at am and continued throughout the day, making threats and abusive comments. He said heaposd blow a BMW up and smash every window in the house, said Mr Espie. One said: aposIaposll get to you before the police get to meapos, and in another he said heaposd boot the baby clean out of her. It was the third reported domestic incident in the last six months, with Fay having previously breached Domestic Violence Protection Notices, which were the result of altercations but not physical violence, the court heard. Melissa Grfiths, defending said Fay has been signed off work sick due to mental health probems. He was diagnosed with bipolar disorder in  and meets regularly with a psychiatrist. Despite being on and off, the pair had been living at separate addresses for the last two years on the recommendation of social services. Ms Griths said Fay is in the process of changing his medication from tablet to liquid form, which has affected his behaviour. She said: That is partly responsible for the way he behaved, but he doesnapost put that forward as an excuse. The messages were extremely frightening and some contained threats. Ms Grfiths said Fay feels extremely ashamed and that the incident was triggered by messages he allegedly received from his ex-partner telling him she might not let him have access to the baby and his other two children. A pre-sentence report was prepared by the probation service which said that the relationship had suffered as a result of Fayaposs deteriorating mental health over the last three years. The incident was the result of a manic episode while he was struggling to get his medication right, but he agreed that being denied contact to his children was not a reasonable excuse for his actions and said he regretted sending the texts. His moods are unstable and he struggled to rationalise them, the probation officer said. Imposing a -week custodial sentence suspended for  months, chair of the bench Sanjay Bhalla said: We have considered the nature of the communications, specically the message saying heaposd kick the baby out, the three previous domestic incidents and the breach of the DVPN. The matter is so serious that custody is the only appropriate option at our disposal. As part of the suspended term, Fay must take part in a -day rehabilitation activity requirement. A restraining order was also imposed, banning him from directly contacting Ms Edwards for two years, save through an agreed third party. He was also ordered to pay £ costs and £ court surcharge.

title: footballer 36 ploughed bmw young
story: NewsFootballer, , ploughed his BMW into young fans who called him FattyLee Taylor, from Port Talbot, denies dangerous driving and  counts of attempting to cause grievous bodily harmShareByLiz Day:,  MAR NewsFootballer Lee Taylor is accused of driving his BMW into a group of young people after losing his temper "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA footballer is accused of mowing down a group of children after being called aposFattyapos during a match, a court has heard. Lee Taylor, , allegedly drove into teenagers like skittles in a bowling alley when banter spilled into violence. He is accused of driving a BMW dangerously and injuring the young people after a game, which his team lost -. Newport Crown Court heard it happened shortly before pm on Thursday, April  last year, Wales Online reports. Prosecutor Christopher Rees said Taylor used his car as a weapon to drive at a group of young people and “mowed them down like skittles in a bowling alley” in a terrying incident. Taylor denies dangerous driving and  counts of attempting to cause grievous bodily harm as well as alternatives of assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Jurors were shown pictures of the scene, and told that the BMW suffered a damaged windscreen and lost a wing mirror in the incident. The young people who were injured in the incident cannot be named for legal reasons. Pictures of injuries to some of the alleged victims were also shown to the court.  Mr Rees said: “The prosecution bring the case, the prosecution have to prove the case. “The prosecution case is that at pm on April , Cornelly Football Club were hosting a match against Margam Football Club. “The defendant Lee Taylor was playing in the football match for Margam. “There were around  to  spectators at the game, most of them young persons.” The court heard one spectator was “giving out banter” to the Margam players. Afterwards a group of young people began to congregate around the changing room. Mr Rees said there was “banter” which provoked one of the young people. “The confrontation was looking like it might escalate towards something more serious, a fight,” said the prosecutor. The court heard Taylor walked back to him BMW, got into the car and reversed out of his parking space. Mr Rees said there were school children in the area. He added: “The prosecution say Taylor got into his car, pointed the nose of the vehicle at the group of young persons, revved and raced his engine, his wheels spun, and drove at speed [towards them].” Mr Rees said he “mowed them down like skittles in a bowling alley”. He added: “It was, the prosecution say, a terrying incident.” One boy described the car’s “wheels spinning” and “engine racing”. The impact caused him to fall backwards ft. Another alleged victim “heard screaming” and “saw the BMW coming directly at him”. Mr Rees said: “He closed his eyes at this point. He felt his body make contact with the grass floor.” The court heard some complainants went on to the bonnet of the car. One teen said he was “scared and speechless”. Another was struck by the car, “causing him to be lted off his feet”. The court heard his face hit the windscreen. Mr Rees said a witness described the scene as “carnage”.  The youngest complainant, aged , said he was “frozen in fear” and “thought he was going to die”. Mr Rees said: “He was lying face down on the bonnet.” The prosecutor said a -year-old girl witnessed the incident, stating: “She saw a group of boys being struck. She was able to record the aftermath of it.” A dog walker saw the car “ploughing into” the group, jurors were told, and mobile phone footage was shown to the court. The court heard there was “a fight” and the defendant used his thumb to “gouge” a complainant’s eye. Prosecutors said Taylor then drove away “at speed”. Police attended the scene at around pm, and went to the Sandfields area of Port Talbot, where Taylor lived. The defendant allegedly told officers: “I wasn’t going to stay and take a kicking.” Mr Rees said the complainants attended hospital and added: “It is by sheer good fortune that the injuries were not more serious than they were.” In his police interview Taylor said he was playing for Margam.  He said he was called “fatty” by one of the boys. Taylor said a youth jumped on his car and said he thought he was going “to get a kicking”. Mr Rees said his account was very dferent from the accounts of the witnesses. The defendant was shown the mobile phone footage and said he did not remember a second “scuffle”. Mr Rees said: “He drove deliberately at these boys.” “The prosecution say the defendant got into his car to drive at the group because he had lost his temper. “He knocked them down like skittles. The prosecution say the defendant is responsible for driving at these young men deliberately.” An -year-old - who was  at the time - said he overheard the defendant say “I’ll eat you, you little c***” to another complainant. He said he was struck by the car in the thigh area, stating: It sort of bounced me on to the floor. I sort of slid across the floor. He said he started apospunchingapos the passenger window, telling the court: He was using the car as a weapon. I wanted to stop him hurting anyone . And describing the attack on him, the teenager said: He approached me. I was down into a headlock. He was gouging my eye. He had his thumb and he was gouging my eye. The court heard police and ambulance attended the scene. the -year-old said he later went to the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend.  Asked about his injuries he said: “I broke my hand. Bruising on my arm, my leg. I had a little lump on my eye.” The jury were shown photographs of his injuries taken by the police. The witness said: “You can see just under my right eye, there’s a bit of a lump, a swelling.” He also suffered grazing and scratching to the back of his leg. The witness said the car hit him to his leg. The teenager told the court he got an injury to his hand by punching the car window. Nicola Powell, for Taylor, suggested some people there “wanted his [Taylor’s] blood”. The teenager disagreed. Ms Powell asked: “I’m right in saying it all kicked off, didn’t it ” The witness replied: “Not necessarily.” Ms Powell suggested one of the complainants “had a score to settle” and was “egged on”. The witness responded: “Not really.” Ms Powell suggested her client was trying to make sure there was “a fair fight”. The teenager replied: “He got involved with straight threats.” Ms Powell suggested some iniduals followed him in the car park, but the witness said that was not the case. The teen said the defendant’s car went on to the grass after hitting him. Ms Powell confirmed her client accepts that his car went on to the playing field briefly to turn around a parked car. The teenager said two iniduals had to run down a lane to get away from the BMW. He said the defendant was “chasing” them. Ms Powell suggested there was “a lot of confusion” and asked the witnesshe could have misinterpreted the defendant’s actions as “chasing”. The witness said he did not believe he had misinterpreted the situation. He agreed the incident happened very quickly and was over in “a couple of minutes”. Ms Powell then suggested her client’s car was “surrounded” by youths. The teeanger said that was not the case. Questioned about what happened to the BMW’s wing mirror, he replied: “I did not see anyone do anything to the wing mirror.” The trial continues.

title: i didnt know demons you
story: NewsI didnt know of the demons you were battling in your head, or what you were forced to do nextTwo years after Charlie Watkins tragically took his own le, his brother Harry has written an emotional letter to his twinShareCommentsByElliott HawkinsLiz Dunphy:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video heartbreaking-death--year-old-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tragic Charlie Watkins looked the picture of happiness, beaming for the camera on TV show Take Me Out. But under the hundred-watt smile, Charlie was mired in darkness, and took his own le in March , before the programme was broadcast. Charlie, a student, was just . He had struggled with his mental health since losing his mother to cancer when he was .His heartbroken twin brother Harry, , has established the Charlie Watkins Foundation to raise awareness about mental health and funds to support young people who are suffering from mental illness.Two years after his death, Harry has written an emotional open letter, published below, about the saddest day of his le and what he would give to see his brother just one more time.   Dear Charlie, It feels strange to write a letter to you now, although it is somewhat therapeutic. I used to think that I knew what you were thinking, yet it is clear to me now that I never truly knew. It is obvious that I did not know of the demons you were battling in your head, or what you were forced to do next. It has been two years since the saddest day of my le.  The day I will never forget, chiselled in my mind like a mason takes to stone, and there it will remain. It serves me not as an infliction of pain, but as a reminder of the work I have to do in your name. Even though you may no longer be with us, your name lives on. The Charlie Watkins Foundation is a symbol, for all those who struggle with the same fight which you so bravely struggled with alone, to show them that there is hope and most importantly, solace.    There is not a day that goes past where I donapost think of you. Watching films we’d seen, eating at restaurants where we’d gone to, and even going to the pub where you so often forgot to take your wallet. What I would give now to buy you one more pint is immeasurable. It is not often someone at the age of  can say that they have lost a brother, furthermore a twin.    It is a connection that is like no other. I constantly feel like there is something missing from my le. I took for granted the bond we shared. I never said I loved you enough or actually admitted you were the quite good-looking brother who had a certain way with words. I lived in awe of your speedy wit and ability to understand a joke a lot quicker than me. I still replay some of your jokes in my head, having a private laugh every now and then.    To be honest, I still donapost quite understand one or two of them. Then again, we always knew who the smarter brother was. Upon undertaking work for the Charlie Watkins Foundation, it became clear that there was a problem out there, and not a small one either. I hadnapost realised that suicide is the biggest killer of men under the age of . How did I not know this  I assumed it was potentially my ignorance, but upon further investigation and talking to friends I realised that they too were none the wiser.  Why is there such a stigma surrounding mental health  If it was cancer or dementia, Iaposm sure everyone would be talking about it. This brought us, the foundation, to one of our key questions and goals. How do we get people to talk about mental health without being scared to do so  This is why we designed Chat with Charlie in your name. It is an online chat-room. A place where students can turn when they are struggling. Hopefully we will be able to spread this nationwide, helping as many as possible. If only there was something like this for you when you were suffering. Charlie, I will never forget you but will learn to cope with living without you. I will carry your memory with me always, as I do with mumaposs. I so often think about what you would be doing now.    What job you would have, where you would live, and what beautul girlfriend you would no doubt have. Sadly though, these are things I will have to leave to the imagination. Take happiness darling brother, knowing that there is always a place in my heart for you to reside, as I know the case to be true with so many others. I wish you eternal love and peace. story: NewsI couldnt leave broken little boy whod lost both legs without a familyDoctors said that Tony may never walk due to the brutal abuse he suffered at the hands of his birth parents - but he has now taken his first stepsShareCommentsByLiz Dunphy:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-tony-hudgell-walking-first-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Paula Hudgell beams with pride as her son Tony takes his first steps. This is a milestone moment for all parents, but for adoptive mum Paula itaposs extra special. Doctors said that four-year-old Tony may never walk due to the brutal abuse he suffered at the hands of his birth parents. At just  days old, Tony was hours from death after being tortured by Jody Simpson, , and Tony Smith, , who were later jailed.Tony suffered multiple organ failure, numerous fractures and  sepsis  and doctors battled for six weeks to save him.The baby was so badly injured that he later had to have both legs amputated below the knee. But that horror is hard to imagine when you look at the smiling, robust little boy wriggling off his mumaposs lap to try out his new Spiderman-themed prosthetic legs. Here, Paula tells their story in her own words.   I can do it mum, I can do it, Tony says as I try to secure his prosthetics before he wriggles off my knee. Seeing him run on his new legs now towards the playground, it’s hard to imagine how close to death he was less than four years ago. He was such a broken little boy when I first met him in hospital. My husband Mark and I were looking to foster a child at the time so we went to see Tony. We were told that he had been poorly but when nurses showed me photos of his injuries I just broke down and cried.  The injuries were horric, his whole body was bruised and he had a hole in his nose. I sat down by his hospital bed and when he opened his eyes he just melted my heart. I rang my husband and said, aposthis is not going to be easy, itaposs going to be a lot of work and our family will never be the same again. But I canapost leave him. When we took him home two days later he looked so fragile in his little car seat. I thought aposwhat have we done bringing such a poorly little boy into our boisterous family apos  But we never wrapped Tony up in cotton wool and he just got on with things. His progress has been incredible. He is proof that all a child needs is love and care to thrive. Nothing stops him now. He’s really fast getting around and he’s caught up cognitively with all his peers. He is very determined. The strength of his will has pulled him through. And these new prosthetics will hopefully be the start of his next phase of growth. Heaposs never been able to walk so we didnapost know how stable he would be.  But he mastered that walking action very quickly so we remain optimistic. Tonyaposs bones are still in a mess after the abuse he suffered. One leg is shorter than the other and when you see him next to other children you really notice how short his thigh bones are. But heaposs using his legs really nicely so weaposre keeping everything crossed. Doctors said that Tony was born in the right era. Medicine and technology are progressing all the time.  In  years, Tony will be , and there should be amazing advancements in prosthetics by then. Theyaposve designed these prosthetics specially for him in Luton. Theyaposre broader at the bottom so theyaposre very stable and have anti-slip rubber on the soles to make it easier for him to learn. Tony loves the playground but he usually has to go down the slide head first. He can tip overhe goes legs-first because all his weight and strength are in his top half but now he can do it with the prosthetics.    The old prosthetics were cumbersome. These have additional layers of lycra which hold his skin more tightly. And heaposll be able to pull up the shorts that attach to the legs on his own. He likes pirates, so he has another pair being sent next week with a skull and cross bones printed on them. Practicing on the prosthetics can be hard work. Heaposs so fast getting around without them that using them can be an inconvenience. Sometimes he says he doesnapost want to do it.    He canapost see the long-term plan, that practicing now could mean that in the future he can walk and stand with his friends. But hopefully this is the start of a new le for him. And Tonyaposs experience may now help to change the law around sentencing for child cruelty. The maximum sentence that can be given for injuring a child is currently  years - thataposs the sentence his birth parents got. And the maximum sentence for killing a child is  years. We want to see those sentences increased and to be brought into line with adult GBH, manslaughter and murder so that a le sentence can be given for injuring or killing children.    Our MP, Tom Tugendhat has been fantastic and he is really pushing to get this bill through. Why should sentences be lower for injuring or killing a vulnerable child  It makes no sense. Tonyaposs Law could change that. Tom is meeting the Justice Minister to see where they can go with the bill now. It was emotional hearing Tom announce that it would be called Tonyaposs Law in the House of Commons. It was a total surprise.The Hudgell family are fundraising for Tony and to pay for disability equipment and treatment. story: NewsStunning pictures show exactly why Brits are proud of our National ParksThese other-worldly photos, celebrating  years of UK parks, will make you want to grab your camera and your walking boots and race out the doorShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  MAR NewsKieran Metcalfes award-winning photo The Dragon and the Flame, taken in the Peak DistrictKieran Metcalfe   Ascent Creative"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe sky’s on fire and the hills really do look like a dragon’s back in this amazing, other-worldly photo. This was not always the case. In s’ Britain, much of the land was off limits to the public, used just a few days a year for grouse shooting.  But thanks to a mass trespass by  courageous and radical ramblers, from Yorkshire’s industrial belt and the Lancashire mill towns, the countryside was opened for all. Five men were jailed for their part in taking to the peak of Kinder Scout in Derbyshire in defiance of the law in April . Ex-Labour deputy leader Roy Hattersley called it “the most successful act of direct action in British history.”  The National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act passed in . Two years later, Britain’s first national park, the Peak District, was created. The most recent was the South Downs, which became a national park in . The parks not only make a signicant contribution to the economy, by attracting  million visitors annually, they have also inspired countless authors, artists and poets. The most popular is the Lake District with . million visitors a year, followed by the Yorkshire Dales.  As long ago as , poet William Wordsworth urged that the patch ofCumberland and Westmoreland in the Lakes should become “national property, in which every man has a right.” Andrew Hall, from the Campaign for National Parks, said: “The parks are the jewels of the country, enriching our lives with beauty, culture, peace and nature.” Here we round up other spectacular entries in the UK National Parks photography competition...

title: how new zealand pm jacinda
story: NewsHow New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern inspired the world - from terror attack response to giving birth in officeThe Prime Minister has only been in office for  months but has already shown there is a dferent way to be a strong and bold leaderShareByMatt Roper:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsEmotional Ms Ardern hugs a mosque-goer at the Kilbirnie Mosque "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn the aftermath of tragedies inspirational people often emerge showing that compassion and love are greater than hate. And the New Zealand mosque terror attacks was no dferent, with accounts of heroism, self-sacrice and acts of forgiveness, despite the unimaginable pain. The country’s Prime Minister, Jacinda Ardern, has also inspired the world with her heartfelt and immediate response to the tragedy. Aged just , her compassionate and heart-felt reaction, has seen her mourn with grieving relatives of the  victims of Friday’s gun massacre. And footage of her holding them, wearing a scarf over her head as a mark of respect, have rendered meaningless -year-old Brenton Tarrant’s own gesture of flashing a white power sign during his court appearance.    Praise for the party leader, who has been in office for nearly  months has been unanimous as she promised to cover funeral costs, provide financial support for families affected and change gun laws. Cristina Nicolotti, Sky News’ director of content, tweeted: “I’ve been incredibly impressed with the compassion, composure and determination shown by Jacinda Ardern in this dreadful crisis. “UK politicians take note.” Sharon Thompson, Labour councillor of North Edgbaston, said the New Zealand PM “has shown the world what true leadership can look like. “Empathy, understanding, action and unity - I applaud this woman for her compassion and not being afraid to lead NZ with real love.” And Islamic Theologian and Scholar Dr Yasir Qadhi spoke for many Muslims around the world when he wrote: “What a noble leader Jacinda Ardern is! A true role model for our times. I might not have known your name before… but you have forever won our respect, and the respect of millions around the globe.”    Within hours of the shooting on Friday morning, the Kiwi leader was already at work to bring her country together and reassure Muslims of their place in her society. “They are us. The person who has perpetuated this violence against us is not,” she said in a moving statement. And she used the same language to speak to the killer, pointing out the New Zealand is made up of people of more than  ethnicities and  languages whose values would not be shaken by the murders. “You may have chosen us - we utterly reject and condemn you,” she said.  The next day she went to Christchurch, taking with her the leaders of all political parties, not just her own. Images of her on the verge of tears, consoling victims’ relatives and hugging the grieving, flew around the world. One photo, in particular, went viral - dressed in a hijab, her face a picture of grief as she listened during a meeting with Christchurch’s Muslim community. And she was seen hugging sobbing relatives tightly and holding their hands outside the city’s Kilbernie mosque, before laying flowers and paying her own tribute to victims at a makesht memorial.    But onlookers have also seen her uncompromising side, in particular in rebuttals she has made to Donald Trump. When asked during a press conference on Saturdayshe agreed with the US presidentaposs comment that he doesn’t see white nationalism as a rising threat, she answered simply: “No.” She also noted that Trump was among the international leaders who called to offer support, saying: “He very much wished for his condolences to be passed on to New Zealand. He asked what support the US could provide. My message was sympathy and love for all Muslim communities.” When she was asked how Trump responded, she said: “He acknowledged that and agreed.” And markedly unlike Trump, rather than simply offering thoughts and prayers she has vowed to ban semi-automatic weapons in the country, saying: “I can tell you one thing right now: Our gun laws will change.” While it took a tragedy for Ms Ardern to come to the attention of many around the world, she has long been seen as an impressive and compassionate leader in New Zealand. She became the youngest sitting MP in Parliament after being elected in  aged just .  The daughter of a veteran New Zealand police officer, she began her career working as a researcher in the office of the then-Prime Minister Helen Clark. She then volunteered in a soup kitchen in New York, before spending three years in the UK as a policy advisor of British PM Tony Blair . Her rise to become New Zealand’s th PM was so meteoric it was dubbed Jacindamania. In March  she was unanimously elected deputy leader of the Labour Party, before taking over as leader in August, then running in - and winning  - the country’s general election the following month. Aged just , she was the youngest Prime Minister in New Zealand for  years. And in office she continued to show that leadership could be dferent.  In her maiden speech, she referred to herself as a social democrat who believes strongly in the values of human rights, social justice, equality, and democracy, and the role of communities. Among many other issues, she is a big advocate of climate change, wants to reduce poverty and homelessness in the country, give young New Zealanders free tertiary education and decriminalise abortion. Known as a frugal leader, soon after she was elected she froze MPs salaries and insisted that her ministers use carpools to get to events. Last year she became only the second world leader in history to give birth while in office - the first was Pakistan’s late two-time PM Benazir Bhutto. By coincidence, at  she was the same age as Bhutto, and gave birth to baby Neve Te Aroha on exactly the same day, June , as the Pakistani leader did  years earlier. New Zealanders were so excited about the birth of her baby hundreds knitted boots and hats, and volunteered for babysitting service, as her due date grew closer.  In September Ms Ardern made history again by becoming the first female leader to attend the United Nations general assembly with her baby in tow. She even played with her three-month-old daughter before giving a speech at the Nelson Mandela peace summit, and while she spoke her partner and stay-at-home dad Clarke Gayford held the baby on his lap. Ms Arden insisted on paying for Clarke’s tickets to New York and other expenses out of her own pocket. Clarke posted a photo on Twitter on Monday of Neve’s security pass, which read “first baby”. He added: “I wish I could have captured the startled look on a Japanese delegation inside UN yesterday who walked into a meeting room in the middle of a nappy change. Great yarn for her st .” Asked by the Today show on the US NBC networkit was harder to govern New Zealand or take her daughter on a -hour flight, Ardern responded with a laugh and said, “it felt at the time on par, adding that she had apologised to her fellow passengers in advance.  And she said she hoped she could help pave the way for other women to be able to work and raise children at the same time. She said: “If I can do one thing, and that is change the way we think about these things, then I will be pleased we have achieved something.” Ms Ardern has also impressed many with her commitment to a kind and more empathetic politics, shown by her refusal to capitalise on mistakes made by opposition leader Simon Brides. She has also been honest about mistakes and shows a willingness to be held to account, an attitude which has led some to criticise her for showing “weakness”. But Dr Claire Timperley, a political scientist at Victoria University believes they are misguided.  She said: “She is putting her neck out by saying ‘I want to claim kindness’ - kindnesses can also be interpreted as weaknesses. “I think she is being very intentional in trying to change the language around leadership, and saying actually you can be kind and you can also be strong.” Through the heartbreaking events of last week, Ms Ardern confounded her critics and showed the world that compassion and kindness can make for strong and bold leadership, something many around the world wish their own leaders would aspire to. The feeling was summed up by the Sydney Morning Herald newspaper, which said in an editorial: “Ardern is a leader for our times, and we should follow her example.”

Silvio Berlusconi coined the term ‘bunga bunga’ to describe the debauched soirees he would throw at his private villa, where young women performed raunchy dancers and strip for him. But when the parties, and allegations that some of the girls were underage, blew up in public the scandal led to the then Italian prime minister being jailed and banned from public office for le. The billionaire media mogul had his sentence quashed a year later on appeal. But bunga bunga could now come back to haunt Belusconi after authorities launched a murder investigation following the mysterious death of a model who was a regular guest at the parties and one of the main witnesses in his trial.    Moroccan Imane Fadil, , died on March  in a Milan hospital, a month after being admitted with stomach pains and telling staff she had been poisoned. Italy’s media have reported she may have been poisoned with a radioactive substances, while Milan’s chief prosecutor said there are “several anomalies” in her medical records. Ms Fadil, who told Berlusconi’s trial that young women wore nun’s costumes and stripped off while performing raunchy pole dances, was writing a book after her experiences at the bunga bunga parties with more potentially explosive revelations, according to reports. Until now Berlusconi, who served as Italian PM in four governments and, once owned football club AC Milan and who owns the country’s largest commercial broadcaster, may have thought he had escaped the sex scandal relatively unscathed. Commenting on Ms Fadil’s death, he continued to deny her claims that she attended his parties or that he paid women for sex. He said: “It’s always a pity when a young person dies. I never met this person, never talked to her. “What I read of her statements made me think that everything was invented, absurd.”    The secretive bunga bunga sessions first came to light in October , when Berlusconi personally phoned a police station asking for the release of a -year-old girl, Karima el-Mahroug, who had been accused of stealing a ,-euro bracelet. He wrongly told them that the girl was the niece of former Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak. In fact the teenager was a Moroccan nightclub dancer and prostitute who called herself Ruby the Heart Stealer. Berlusconi, prosecutors later claimed, was terried police questioning her would find out that underage Ruby had been attending the ‘bunga bunga’ parties held at his palatial home, Villa San Martino, in Arcore, a small town outside of Milan. Following the phone call officers released her into the care of one of the prime minister’s associates, Nicole Minetti, a member of Berlusconi’s party who also pimped for the mogul and performed explicit lesbian floorshows in a nun’s costume. She took Ruby back to a flat she shared with a Brazilian prostitute, Michelle Conceicao, who was also later linked with Berlusconi after it was found she called him on his mobile phone while he was attending a summit in Paris.  But when prosecutors found out about PM’s intervention in her arrest, they began an investigation would culminate in one of the country’s most sensational trials. It was Ruby who first introduced the term ‘bunga bunga’, which she said was a lap-dancing competition in which the winner or winners got to sleep with Berlusconi. In an interview with prosecutor Antonio Sangermano soon after the police station incident, she claimed Berlusconi had sent a limo to her home to take her to the villa for the first time on Valentine’s Day . She said: “That evening Berlusconi explained to me that bunga bunga consisted of a harem that he copied from his friend Gaddafi , in which the girls take their clothes off and have to provide physical pleasures.” While Berlusconi never denied inviting women to his lavish parties, he always claimed they were “convivial” dinners with food, laughter and jokes, after which he would sometimes give them money because he was “generous” and wanted to help them.  But as more women came forward with lurid details of what would happen at the private bashes the case transfixed and shocked Italians. Prosecution documents listed the names of  young women, mostly would-be starlets hoping to break into showbusiness on one of Berlusconi’s television channels, who said were paid to have sex with him at the parties. They described how the parties always followed the same script, and ended with the prime minister choosing one of the girls to spent the night with. First, they said, came dinner, a meal often composed of foods in the red, white and green of Italy’s tricolor flag. Then followed what has become known as the ‘bunga bunga’ session, “which took place in a disco-like room where the female participants engaged in dressing up, striptease and erotic dances, touching each other or touching and being touched in their intimate parts by Silvio Berlusconi. Finally, at the end of the evening, -year-old Berlusconi would choose “one or more women with whom he spent the night in an intimate relationship, in exchange for money, expensive gts or rent-free apartments.  Some of the most eye-opening accounts of what happened at the mogul’s mansion came from Ambra Battilana and Chiara Danese, two women who had been wooed to a bunga bunga party with promises of jobs on Berlusconi’s TV channel. Ms Battilana said: Fteen minutes after we’d sat down, some of the girls uncovered their breasts, offering them to Berlusconi so he could kiss them. “They also touched the prime minister’s intimate parts and made him touch theirs. “While this was happening, the girls were still singing “thank goodness for Silvio!” and calling the prime minister “Papi” and Berlusconi called all of us “my little girls, my little girls. And Ms Danese claimed the PM asked women to kill the penis of a statue. The statuette is the size of a half-litre bottle of water. Its penis is disproportionately big. “Berlusconi begins passing it around among the girls. And he asks them to kiss the penis. They kiss it and simulate oral sex with it, or they approach him with bared breasts. They all laugh. “At a certain point, the prime minister, visibly content, asks: “Are you ready for bunga bunga ” The girls shout together: “Yessss!!!” The police investigation also used wiretaps of women’s phones to get evidence of what happened during the secretive soirees. In the transcript of one call, party guest Maria Makdoum told how she did a belly dance in the ‘bunga bunga’ room while a pair of twin sisters, dressed in bra and panties, danced around “in a hard-core way” before Berlusconi and another male guest. “The other girls also danced, showing their breasts and their bottoms and they all went near the prime minister who touched them in their intimate parts,” she said.  In another leaked transcript Dario ‘Lele’ Mora - a TV impresario accused with others of procuring prostitutes for the premier - asked one woman: “Do you have a nurse’s outfit  Go get one today,” adding that she should wear nothing underneath except white suspenders for a “private health visit.” He was one of three Berlusconi aides accused of being part of a “vast pimping network” to attend bunga bunga parties with the prime minister. Police also tapped the calls of women to Berlusconi himself, some of which were leaked to Italian media. Testying at the trial, Imane Fadil - the woman who died this month - said the parties involved young women, sometimes in pairs, wearing nuns’ costumes and stripping off while performing raunchy pole dances. She said: “They started to dance like the nuns of the film ‘Sister Act’ and then they took off their clothes.” At another party, a woman in her underwear stripped for Berlusconi wearing a mask with the face of footballer Ronaldinho, she said. story: NewsRuth Maguire: Mystery final moments of mum who vanished and died after hen partyMum-of-three Ruth Maguire, , went missing as the hen party group left a pub in Carlingford, County Louth, IrelandShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe missing mum was found dead "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMystery surrounds the final movements of a young mum who went missing after a hen party and drowned in a nearby lough. Her friends issued a desperate appeal after she was last seen at .pm on Saturday night. A search was launched and her body was found in Carlingford Lough on Monday. Her friends immediately tried to find Ruth, from Newcastle, County Down, but there was no sign of her. Her coat had been left at the bar and her phone had been turned off.    CCTV captured the mum-of-three walking towards an area of water at Carlingford Lough after leaving Taaffeaposs bar in the town centre. Itaposs believed she had told a doorman she was going to make her way back to Newcastle. Ruth then took a picture of a house across the road from the lough and posted it on social media around midnight.  Itaposs believed Ruth fell into the water after leaving the pub and drowned.    The -year-oldaposs friends noticed she was missing when they arrived back at their rented accommodation and realised she had become separated from the group. Bridesmaid Katrina O’Hare said on Sunday: “We thought she was going to head home to Newcastle because she had said to a bouncer she was going to get to Newcastle from here but her partner and kids were at her mum’s house in Ligoniel. “He drove down today and she was not there. Her mobile is going straight to voicemail. It was .pm last night she was last seen.”Her friend Seana McMullan posted on Facebook on Sunday: “It’s now been a full  hours since Ruth Maguire has been seen.“She was separated from our hen party in Carlingford and we assumed she wouldby morning after a few of the girls searched for her”.  Ruth was engaged to her partner James Grfin and was mum to Lydia, Oliver and Tyler. Nathan Leneghan, a member of the RNLI involved in the discovery of Ruth’s body, said it was a “sad time”.He told the Irish Mirror: “At .pm on Monday Newcastle RNLI commenced a search at the entrance to Carlingford Lough and outlying islands.“During this search the leboat located a casualty in the water who was taken to Greenore Harbour by Kilkeel leboat and placed in the care of An Garda Siochana. “On behalf of Newcastle RNLI, I wish our deepest sympathy to the family and friends of the woman who was recovered from the water.”  A Garda spokesman said: “The hunt for a missing -year-old woman has been stood down following the discovery of a body of a woman in Carlingford Lough. “The body is believed to be that of missing woman Ruth Maguire. “Gardai wish to thank the public for their help in this instance.” A postmortem will be carried out but it is understood to be a tragic event.

title: waitress disappeared after leaving celebrity
story: NewsWaitress disappeared after leaving celebrity Costa del Sol club with two BritsCCTV showed Agnese Klavina appeared to be forced into Westley Capper’s Mercedes before he drove off with friend Craig Porter, a court heardShareByGerard Couzens:,  MAR NewsAgnese Klavina was  when she vanished in September  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman disappeared without trace after leaving a celebrity Costa del Sol nightclub with two British men, a court was told. CCTV footage showed Agnese Klavina, , appeared to be forced into Westley Capper’s Mercedes S before he drove off with pal Craig Porter, judges were told at the start of the Britsapos kidnap trial. Both have denied unlawful detention. Police investigating the mysterious disappearance said they categorised it as potentially “high-risk” from the start and arrested the Brits after discovering Miss Klavina was last seen leaving Aqwa Mist nightspot, in the upmarket resort of Puerto Banus, with them. Her phone stopped emitting a signal around five hours later, said police, who have been unable to locate her more than four years on.  Essex-born Capper, , and Porter,  could be sentenced to up to  years in prisonconvicted of unlawful detention. They took the witness stand at Malaga’s Audiencia Provincial court to deny “making Agnese disappear” or disposing of her body at sea. The Latvian-born waitress spent several years living in London before moving to the Costa del Sol around six months before she disappeared in the early hours of September , . A three-page state prosecution indictment submitted to the court ahead of the start of the trial on Monday claims the Brit pair asked Miss Klavina to accompany them to Capper’s home on the exclusive El Madronal residential estate a -minute drive from Aqwa Mist.  Prosecutor Maria del Carmen Tirado Galvez added in the indictment: “Westley George Capper took advantage of the fact she was under the effects of alcohol and and her intellectual and volitive faculties were affected and led her to his Mercedes S AMG car. “Agnese caused a fuss as she was led from the door of the nightclub to the car and showed she didn’t want to accompany the accused. “Despite this Westley George Capper put her into the vehicle which he was driving, while Craig Ian Porter who was in the passenger seat was waiting inside. “Agnese tried to get out of the car once she was inside but was prevented from doing so by the accused who then sped off towards El Madronal, both of them retaining Agnese Klavina against her will. “Since then there has been no news of her and the accused have not offered any information on her whereabouts.”  Capper, wearing a white shirt and black trousers in court, admitted drinking beer and vodka and taking drugs the night Miss Klavina vanished. But he insisted under oath she got into his car “willingly” after they met in the club and agreed to go back to his home to carry on partying despite failing to persuade a girlfriend she was with to accompany them. He refused to answer questions from lawyers acting for Miss Klavina’s family, but told the state prosecutor he was holding her by the waist as they left Aqwa Mist because she was “drunk and staggering. Private-school educated Capper said he dropped Miss Klavina off near a roundabout around three minutes drive from his home after she told him: “Stop here, I’ve changed my mind, I want to go home, this is where I live.” Prosecutor Maria del Carmen Tirado Galvez asked Capper during cross-examination: “Did you not think it’s strange that she wanted to be left at am in high heels more than two kilometres from her home ” Capper replied: “It was a well-lit area and I knew the turning near where I dropped her was full of houses. She said that’s where her house was and I didn’t know at the time she lived any further.”  He also insisted a number of  calls from his phone the morning Miss Klavina disappeared were made by accident and said he made repeated calls to a British friend called Paul Farmer who was questioned but never charged to try to buy drugs off him. Police records show he called his pal’s phone  times between .am and .am before ringing him repeatedly later the same morning. Asked about a suitcase and a carpet seen being taken onto Capper’s boat four days after Agnese’s disappearance when it was boarded by four men including the two defendants, he said: “I wasn’t carrying a carpet. I was carrying a case but it had clothes in it and bedding for the boat because I was planning to go to Ibiza for the closing parties.” Porter, the first of the two men to take the witness stand, insisted he fell asleep in the passenger seat on the ride home to Capper’s house and only discovered Miss Klavina was no longer with them when they reached his friendaposs home. Asked by his defence lawyer Inmaculada Garciahe intended to have sex with Miss Klavina, he answered No” and said the only reason he did not go straight home despite being “drunk and tired” was because he did not want to wake his we and children. He admitted to going out to sea on his pal’s boat Geofil II from Puerto de la Duquesa near Gibraltar on September , .  His defence lawyer asked him: “On that day did you or anyone you were with dispose of Agnese’s body ” Porter replied: “No.” Porter admitted to seeing missing posters shortly after Miss Klavina vanished but insisted he had never looked at them properly and could not remember what she had looked like. Aqwa Mist doorman Siani Ousmane, who is accused of being an accessory to the Brits’ alleged crime only by prosecutors for Miss Klavina’s family, told the court he had been asked to throw the pair out of the club by his boss because they were causing problems but insisted the missing woman never asked for his help. He described Miss Klavina as a regular at the nightclub. He insisted he only opened the Mercedes car door for Porter in the hope of a tip to supplement his meagre  euroa night wage - and said the missing blonde got in the vehicle herself and he did not push her in. A National Police investigator, referred to in court only by his service number  and not his name, said Miss Klavina had a steady job and friends and had given no indication she was unhappy. He told the court: “The CCTV footage we obtained from the nightclub showed she did not appear to be acting with her full will.

title: busy section of dundee road to close for 10 days
story: A half-mile stretch of one of Dundee’s busiest roads is set to close for  days in order to install a new pedestrian crossing.A HALF-mile stretch of one of Dundee’s busiest roads is set to close for  days in order to install a new pedestrian crossing.The A Arbroath Road will be shut between Fairfield Road and Claypotts Road from April  so the traffic lights can be erected, linking Dawson and Claypotts parks.It will be closed both ways during the works, with the council hoping to reopen the road by April .Residents’ access to their homes is unlikely to be affected by the works. However, disruption for road users is expected as a result of the closure.Diversions could redirect traffic on to nearby Dundee Road, where drivers can rejoin Claypotts Road at its southernmost point and continue their journeys on the A.Ferry councillor Craig Duncan said he welcomed the move to link up the two parks.The works bear a similarity to a project to do the same across the Kingsway at Caird Park, which is almost complete.Mr Duncan said: “It looks as though it will link up the two parks. It can be tricky crossing there when you have kids or dogs.“It’ll be good to join them up in a safe way and I’m looking forward to them going in.”The works are the second major project to impact Arbroath Road users in less than  months.The pothole-pocked road was closed for two weeks last July for signicant resurfacing works.Similarly, the latest set of works will take place during the spring school holidays.Mr Duncan added: “There is never an excellent time to do roadworks but they have tried to do these at a time when they are least likely to have an impact on a lot of people, which is to be commended.”Elsewhere in Dundee, another street is set to close for two weeks during the spring holidays for the installation of a second pedestrian crossing.Old Glamis Road south of the Kingsway will close between Balgray Street and Fairmuir Road starting on April  for pedestrian crossing works.That closure will impact on bus services, including Xplore Dundee’s  which will ert via Park Road, Strathmartine Road and Clepington Road before resuming its route towards the city centre.The service heading out of the city, towards Kirkton, will not be affected by the works.

title: dundee boss jim mcintyre keeping tabs on st mirren and hamilton
story: Jim McIntyre admits he’ll be keeping a keen eye on how St Mirren and Hamilton are faring tomorrow ahead of his side’s clash with Celtic on Sunday.The Dark Blues will take on the league leaders following the Buddies’ trip to St Johnstone and Hamilton’s home clash with Hearts.In an ideal world, it would be all about focusing on themselves at Dens Park, as the manager has been keen to stress in recent weeks, but the nature of the three-way battle to avoid the drop means the Dark Blues can’t help but take notice of their rivals’ results.And Jim would be delighted to shock everybody, St Mirren and Accies included, by picking up a result against the Hoops this weekend.Jim said: “A big result against a big side would do wonders for confidence levels.“You have to look to pick up points against teams you’re not expected to.“That can also have an effect on others, as well as boosting yourselves.“I’ll go back to it, though – we can only worry about us.“Obviously we hope that other results go our way.“I’m not going to sit here and kid on I’m not.“There were a lot of positives against Hearts but we’ve lost the game and there are only so many times you can keep saying that.“We know we need to be better in the final third.”Jim isn’t expecting much of a change to Celtic from their last meeting, despite Neil Lennon replacing the departed Brendan Rodgers last month.“Why would you want to change what has been very successful ” he added.“I’m sure Neil will make subtle changes because every manager does that but the bottom line is their squad is still the same and they’ve still got top players.“We need a top performance to get anything out of the game.”Dundee are expected to be without striker Andrew Nelson but Craig Curran came through last week’s clash with Hearts unscathed after his stomach injury saw him miss the - defeat at Ibrox last Wednesday.Both Andy Dales and Scott Wright picked up knocks against the Jambos but nothing that will keep them out of Sunday’s clash.

title: dundee boss mcintyre refuses to blame referee for celtic loss after 96th minute goal
story: Boss Jim McIntyre believes the six minutes of injury time played by Bobby Madden at Dens Park yesterday was too long.However, the Dundee gaffer refused to blame the referee for the heart-breaking loss to Celtic that came via an Odsonne Edouard strike in the final few seconds of that extra period.When he did finally blow for time, home supporters booed the whistler off the park and clearly believed he’d cost their team a point.For Jim, though, the failure to take an excellent opportunity to snatch victory just seconds earlier was the cause of his team’s agonising demise.That came when substitute Andy Dales shot straight at Hoops keeper Scott Bain from the edge of the area when a better option seemed to play a pass.It allowed Celtic to go up the park and capitalise on an error by home skipper Martin Woods and grab the winner.“I fail to see where six minutes comes from. I thought that was too much time added on but, having said that, it’s not the reason,” he said.“We had a great opportunity on the counter attack with two minutes to go and we’ve got to be better.“That’s the reason we are where we are because we’ve been going into so many good areas in each of the last few games and we’re not punishing teams.“We didn’t do what Celtic did. They were ruthless and that’s why we’ve not picked up enough points since I’ve come.“There has been plenty of positive play, plenty of areas we’ve got into but we need to be better in the final third.“It’s the only thing that’s going to get you out of the situation that you’re in – winning games.”Returning to Madden’s decision to play on for so long, Jim confirmed he had spoken to the referee to get his reasoning.“He said there were a couple of head knocks, so that was the reason why. It’s generally about three but there were a couple of knocks, so I could understand maybe four. Six was a surprise.”The defeat, along with Hamilton Accies’ surprise win over Hearts on Saturday, means Dundee are now six points from safety down in the top flight drop zone.The postponement of St Mirren’s game at St Johnstone on Saturday because of snow means the Dark Blues remain a point above bottom.

title: dundee face mammoth task against celtic but every point is vital says darren odea
story: Every point is vital for Dundee now but experienced defender Darren O’Dea acknowledges they’ve got a “mammoth effort” ahead of them to get any from Celtic on Sunday.The league leaders and reigning champions head to Dens Park for a lunchtime kick-off on Sunday time as clear favourites to pick up the three points on offer.That would take them one step closer to an eighth-straight title but Irish international O’Dea has no interest in that despite his history with the Parkhead club – his only worry is getting points on the board for the Dark Blues.With the business end of the season on the horizon, the -year-old knows it’s vital Dundee get a leg up on their relegation rivals Hamilton and St Mirren.Despite the Dens men being as much as   with some bookies to pick up a victory, O’Dea has been part of Dundee sides that have picked up results against the Hoops – three goalless draws since his arrival in January .He told the Tele: “Every game is vital but Sunday doesn’t get much harder.“There have been games recently where we could’ve got more out of.“Since I’ve been here we’ve picked up some results against them both home and away but, one thing is for sure, it takes a mammoth effort.“It needs every player to be near the top of their game and we aim to do that this weekend.“It will be dficult and take a huge amount of effort but I don’t think effort is something we’ll have to worry about –we can get that wee bit of quality we’ve lacked at certain times, hopefully, we can pick up a result.”Dundee go into Sunday’s contest on the back of a poor run of form, losing their last three league matches against Hibs, Rangers and then Hearts.It’s not all doom and gloom for O’Dea, however, after an improved display in the - loss to the Jambos at Dens Park last Saturday.With chances spurned and a poor goal conceded, the Edinburgh side left with the points but the centre-half says Dundee can take a lot from their performance into Sunday, evenCeltic’s fluid frontline brings a dferent threat to the direct and physical approach from Craig Levein’s men last week.“Hearts aren’t embarrassed at the way they play and they shouldn’t be, they won the game, but Celtic will be a completely dferent style of play,” O’Dea said.“There are dferent ways to play against that, none of them easy, but the manager will figure out which way we go about it and we know we’re at the stage where every point is vital.”He added: “The Hearts game was scrappy, their style made it that way which is fine but they were very direct but they didn’t create too much.“The goal was an absolute stramash with bodies all over the place and they had Morrison with a shot just after but, bar that, I can’t think of any more shots they had on goal.“We were structured well as a team but we looked dangerous and for it being a really scrappy game we were the ones who created the moments of quality in the game.“For a final ball or a finish, % it wouldn’t have been undeserved to get a point or maybe more but we didn’t.“Now that’s neither here nor there, Hearts have three points and we don’t, but we can take positives from the performance.“We are in the business end of the season so it’s only results that matter but, in terms of endeavour and chances created, there are positives.”

title: dundee pride 2019 to be bigger than last year say organisers
story: The time and location of Dundee Pride  has been announced — and it looks certain to be a bigger affair than last year’s inaugural march.Slessor Gardens will become a sea of rainbow colours when it hosts the festival on Saturday September .Dundee Pride co-chairmen Tim Kelly and Tommy Small made the announcement at Klozet Bar, as well as outlining the timeline for the march’s organisation.No acts have been confirmed yet but anyone who wants to get involved can make their interest known between April  and June .The same dates apply for prospective stall holders. It is hoped a line-up can then be announced on July .The final route for the march has not been finalised either but is likely to start somewhere in the city centre before finishing at Slessor Gardens.Tim said: “We’re really excited. It will be great to have our village in Slessor Gardens.“The council has been a great support to help us secure the location. We’re working with lots of local LGBT organisations to really make it bigger.”Tommy said: “Slessor Gardens is a massive space, but with the amount of people that came last year we knew we’d have to find a bigger venue.”He also appealed to anyone keen on volunteering, whether on the day itself or to help with the planning and preparation, to contact Dundee Pride.Last year’s event exceeded expectations, with an estimated , people attending.Slessor Gardens has a capacity of around , people. It has hosted big name acts such as Rita Ora, UB and Steps. Primal Scream also performed there to mark the opening of the VA last year.Tom Jones and Craig David are set to play at the venue this summer.

story: Dundee United#s game at Dunfermline has been called off.The referee has deemed the East End Park pitch unplayable due to being waterlogged.The Fe club had released a statement at am saying there were no plans to hold a pitch inspection because the pitch was considered playable.
